Patch 1.23 is another bug squasher
 Developer CD Projekt Red rolled out a new patch for Cyberpunk 2077 on Thursday, patch 1.23, that squashes more bugs and fixes a variety of quest-related issues in the first-person shooter. The patch arrives just days before Cyberpunk 2077 is set to return to Sony‚Äôs PlayStation Store, after a six-month absence.
Console players will therefore be pleased to read that patch 1.23 for Cyberpunk 2077 promises ‚Äúnumerous crash fixes in animations, UI, scene, physics and gameplay systems‚Äù and ‚Äúvarious console CPU optimizations,‚Äù according to CD Projekt Red‚Äôs patch notes. The developer says the update will reduce the number of overall crashes.
Elsewhere, the patch appears to primarily address quest and open-world bugs, a list of which‚Ä¶
articles.title: Cyberpunk 2077‚Äôs latest patch fixes more bugs ahead of PS4 re-release

articles.description:
Image: EA Tiburon/Electronic Arts
    

  
EA Sports also promises substantial additions, demanded by the community, to Madden‚Äôs franchise mode
 It was a preseason game, Clint Oldenburg said. ‚ÄúNot a regular season game, not a playoff game.‚Äù The crowd in Seattle still annihilated his ability to think.
‚ÄúWhen I was at the line of scrimmage, I couldn‚Äôt hear anything. All I could hear was the crowd,‚Äù said Oldenburg, today Madden NFL 22‚Äôs gameplay producer, back then an offensive lineman trying to make the Denver Broncos‚Äô 53-man roster. 
Yes, home-field advantage is real, Oldenburg said. With crowds returning after a pandemic year quieted the NFL‚Äôs stadiums last fall, they‚Äôll be a more noticeable part of the league‚Äôs video game, too. But a home field‚Äôs challenge won‚Äôt simply be in ramped-up volu‚Ä¶

articles.description:
When I write about programming, I spend a lot of time trying to come up with
good examples. I haven‚Äôt seen a lot written about how to make examples, so
here‚Äôs a little bit about my approach to writing examples!
The basic idea here is to start with real code that you wrote and then remove
irrelevant details to make it into a self-contained example instead of coming
up with examples out of thin air.
I‚Äôll talk about two kinds of examples: realistic examples and suprising
examples.
good examples are realistic
To see why examples should be realistic, let‚Äôs first talk about an unrealistic
example! Let‚Äôs say we‚Äôre trying to explain Python lambdas (which is just the
first concept I thought of). You could give this example, of using map and a
lambda to double a set of numbers.
numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4‚Ä¶
articles.title: Write good examples by starting with real code

articles.description:
I have been trying not to read too much about Morgan Neville‚Äôs documentary Roadrunner: A Film About Anthony Bourdain before I have had a chance to watch it, but the few things I have read about it have given me some pause. From Helen Rosner‚Äôs piece about the film drawn from an interview with Neville:
There is a moment at the end of the film‚Äôs second act when the artist David Choe, a friend of Bourdain‚Äôs, is reading aloud an e-mail Bourdain had sent him: ‚ÄúDude, this is a crazy thing to ask, but I‚Äôm curious‚Äù Choe begins reading, and then the voice fades into Bourdain‚Äôs own: ‚Äú‚Ä¶and my life is sort of shit now. You are successful, and I am successful, and I‚Äôm wondering: Are you happy?‚Äù I asked Neville how on earth he‚Äôd found an audio recording of Bourdain reading his own e-mail. Throughout the ‚Ä¶
articles.title: An AI Bourdain Speaks From the Grave

articles.description:
During a Tonight Show appearance in 1978, Johnny Carson asked Carl Sagan about the scientific accuracy of Star Wars. Sagan replied:
The 11-year-old in me loved them but they could have made a better effort to to do things right. A lot of different aspects of things ‚Äî Star Wars starts out saying it‚Äôs on some other galaxy and then you see there‚Äôs people. Starting in scene one there‚Äôs a problem, because human beings are the result of a unique evolutionary sequence based upon so many individually unlikely random events on the Earth.
In fact, I think most evolutionary biologists would agree that if you started the Earth out again and just let those random factors operate you might wind up with beings that are as smart as us and as ethical and artistic and all the rest, but they would not be human beings. That‚Äôs for the Earth. So in another planet, different environment, very unlikely to have a human being. It‚Äôs extremely unlikely that there would be creatures as similar to us as as the dominant ones in Star Wars.
And a whole bunch of other things: they‚Äôre all white. The skin of all the humans in Star Wars, oddly enough, is like this. And not even the other colors represented on the Earth at present, much less greens and blues and purples and oranges.


Carson pushes back slightly at this point: ‚ÄúThey did have the scene of Star Wars with a lot of strange characters.‚Äù But Sagan persists:
Yeah, but none of them seem to be in charge of the galaxy. Everybody in charge of the galaxy seemed to look like us. And I thought it was a large amount of human chauvinism.


Sagan also complained about Han Solo‚Äôs boast of doing the Kessel Run in less than 12 parsecs. According to the script, this was an ‚Äúobvious‚Äù lie on Han‚Äôs part to make his ship sound impressive, so Sagan missed that. But then, post-Lucas, the Kessel Run was explained in Solo: A Star Wars Story as a distance shortcut and not an elapsed completion time, so‚Ä¶. (via digg)
Tags: Carl Sagan¬†¬† Johnny Carson¬†¬† movies¬†¬† racism¬†¬† Star Wars¬†¬† video
articles.title: Carl Sagan in 1978: Star Wars Is Too White

I posted about the 2021 Audubon Photography Awards earlier today, but I wanted to highlight Bill Bryant‚Äôs award-winning clip of a red-tailed hawk. The hawk is hunting, floating on the wind searching for small prey, its head perfectly still while its body stabilizes around it. I could watch this clip on repeat for the rest of the day‚Ä¶so cool!
This is not just a thing that hawks do ‚Äî see also This Owl Will Not Move His Head and The Eerie Stillness of Chicken Heads. Birds: nature‚Äôs steadycams.

articles.title: The Perfect Head Stabilization of a Hunting Red-Tailed Hawk

articles.description:
Filmmaker James Robinson has an eye condition he calls ‚Äúwhale eyes‚Äù that causes him to see differently than (and look differently to) most people. In this short film, he makes a plea to ‚Äúnormal‚Äù people for acceptance of his and others‚Äô differences.
But his video is also an essay on seeing, in the deeper sense of the word ‚Äî seeing and being seen, recognition and understanding, sensitivity and compassion, the stuff of meaningful human connection.
In a society that does a lousy job of accommodating the disabled, Mr. Robinson appeals for more acceptance of people who are commonly perceived as different or not normal.
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have a problem with the way that I see,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúMy only problem is with the way that I‚Äôm seen.‚Äù


 Tags: disability¬†¬† James Robinson¬†¬† video
articles.title: ‚ÄúI Want You To Look Me In the Eye‚Äù

articles.description:
There‚Äôs new short fiction from Sally Rooney in the New Yorker: Unread Messages.
For the rest of the afternoon in the office, the woman worked on the same text-editing interface, moving apostrophes and deleting commas. After closing one file and before opening another, she routinely checked her social-media feeds. Her expression, her posture, did not vary depending on the information she encountered there: a news report about a horrific natural disaster, a photograph of someone‚Äôs beloved pet, a female journalist speaking out about death threats, a recondite joke requiring familiarity with several other previous Internet jokes in order to be even vaguely comprehensible, a passionate condemnation of white supremacy, or a promoted tweet advertising a health supplement for expectant mothers. Nothing changed in her outward relationship to the world that would allow an observer to determine what she felt about what she saw. Then, after some length of time, with no apparent trigger, she closed the browser window and reopened the text editor. Occasionally one of her colleagues would interject with a work-related question and she would answer, or someone would share a funny anecdote with the office and they would all laugh, but mostly the work continued quietly.


Per an interview with Rooney, the piece is excerpted from her next novel, Beautiful World, Where Are You, due out in September and eagerly anticipated in this household.
Tags: Sally Rooney
articles.title: Unread Messages by Sally Rooney

articles.description:
This is quite a paragraph from David Bentley Hart‚Äôs Three Cheers for Socialism in Commonweal:
Americans are, of course, the most thoroughly and passively indoctrinated people on earth. They know next to nothing as a rule about their own history, or the histories of other nations, or the histories of the various social movements that have risen and fallen in the past, and they certainly know little or nothing of the complexities and contradictions comprised within words like ‚Äúsocialism‚Äù and ‚Äúcapitalism.‚Äù Chiefly, what they have been trained not to know or even suspect is that, in many ways, they enjoy far fewer freedoms, and suffer under a more intrusive centralized state, than do the citizens of countries with more vigorous social-democratic institutions. This is at once the most comic and‚Ä¶
articles.title: America‚Äôs Abstract Freedom

articles.description:
This is an animation of how quickly an object falls 1 km to the surfaces of solar system objects like the Earth, Sun, Ceres, Jupiter, the Moon, and Pluto. For instance, it takes 14.3 seconds to cover that distance on Earth and 13.8 seconds on Saturn.
It might be surprising to see large planets have a pull comparable to smaller ones at the surface, for example Uranus pulls the ball down slower than at Earth! Why? Because the low average density of Uranus puts the surface far away from the majority of the mass. Similarly, Mars is nearly twice the mass of Mercury, but you can see the surface gravity is actually the same‚Ä¶ this indicates that Mercury is much denser than Mars.


(via @thekidshouldsee)
Tags: astronomy¬†¬† gravity¬†¬† infoviz¬†¬† physics¬†¬† science¬†¬† video
articles.title: Visualization of How Fast a Ball Drops on Various Solar System Bodies

articles.description:
For more than 21 years, Noah Kalina has taken a photograph of himself. Periodically, he makes video compilations of the photos ‚Äî you‚Äôve probably seen them here or elsewhere. For his latest video, he‚Äôs collaborated with Michael Notter (visuals) and Paul O‚ÄôMara (sound) on a video called 7777 Days.
In a first step, Michael used the machine learning library dlib (http://dlib.net/) and some custom Python code to detected in each of Noah‚Äôs photos 5 face landmarks (i.e. both eyes, the nose and the two corners of the mouth). These landmarks were then used to align the faces in all photos, so that the eyes and corner of the mouth were horizontally oriented and always an equal distance apart. After that, some small image intensity correction were applied to make very dark images a bit brighter and very bright ones a bit darker. This was followed by an upscaling of all images (where needed) to a 4K resolution.


The result is a 2-minute video (reminiscent of Jason Salavon‚Äôs work) that spans half of Kalina‚Äôs life ‚Äî in the video he ages 2 months every second and 10 years a minute.
Tags: mesmerizing¬†¬† Michael Notter¬†¬† Noah Kalina¬†¬† Paul O‚ÄôMara¬†¬† photography¬†¬† video
articles.title: Half a Life in 2 Minutes

Slow and reverby, the singer‚Äôs perhaps-least-favorite Radiohead song takes on new life for this (second?) oddest of years. On first listen, I like but maybe don‚Äôt love this version, but some of the YT comments are worth reading:
Can‚Äôt believe Thom Yorke finally collaborated with Radiohead. Two of my favorite artists making a song together



Thom has went so far into artistic discovery he looped back on himself. It‚Äôs like post-post-irony, but musically

Thom nailed this one, he sounds just like the originals singer!


You can find the song on a variety of platforms.

articles.description:
Car and Driver has a good article that both assesses the brief history of electric car design and looks at where things might be headed going forward, as designers break free of some early conceptions about what a car (or what a specifically electric car) needed to look like. Some highlights:
 Many early EV ventures used existing platforms and arranged electric powertrains to fit where gas engines and transmissions had previously resided. Even Tesla‚Äôs first attempt was a revamped Lotus Elise without its 1.8-liter inline-four. Working on a nondedicated, or ‚Äúnonnative,‚Äù electric platform limited designers‚Äô options for positioning the battery and motor. Automakers often stacked batteries under the rear seat‚Äîwhich is why early EVs sometimes offered less legroom or cargo space than their gas co‚Ä¶
articles.title: The History and Future of Electric Car Design

articles.description:
Vice has a sometimes less-than-flattering profile of Best Electronics‚Äô Bradley Koda, a persnickety entrepreneur who has an unrivaled catalog of old-school Atari console parts and a reputation for shutting out buyers who get impatient with doing things his way:
Among Atari fans, Best is almost as famous for ignoring and blacklisting badly behaved customers as it is for selling Atari parts. A first attempt to buy from Best Electronics is a sink-or-swim proposition: learn the rules, or accept your fate‚Ä¶
Koda is a monopolist, of a sort, but he‚Äôs no Jeff Bezos. Best Electronics has no virtual shopping cart, or any other Amazon-esque conveniences. The store‚Äôs website looks the same as it has since the early 2000s: it‚Äôs a lengthy, multicoloured text scroll, as if Jack Kerouac quit the novel-writing business (but not the benzedrine) and started typing about Atari‚Ä¶ 
 

Anyone who can‚Äôt figure out this system risks being deemed a time-waster. In emails to customers, Koda often laments his busy schedule, and he seems to take distractions personally. He would rather lose a sale than suffer someone who hasn‚Äôt learned the rules.
 

Best has been in business more than 25 years. Its equipment is mostly unused Atari originals, not salvaged parts. The company‚Äôs catalog was printed more than 20 years ago (and is available only in print); corrections (including changes in price) are only available online. His customers both love him and fear him. 
In short, it‚Äôs a throwback to old-school nerd retail, the kind lampooned by The Simpsons‚Äô Comic Book Guy. What, did you think finding first-rate replacement parts for your forty-year old video game machine would be like buying AA batteries? 
Tags: Atari¬†¬† online¬†¬† video games
articles.title: Just How Badly Do You Want That Replacement Atari Console Part?

articles.description:
Along with a liveblog of the last few rounds of this year‚Äôs Scripps National Spelling Bee, The New York Times has an excellent profile of its champion, 14 year-old Zaila Avant-garde from New Orleans, Louisiana. (One fun fact: Zaila‚Äôs last name is an homage by her father to John Coltrane.)
 Zaila, who just finished eighth grade in her hometown, Harvey, La., showed a prowess for spelling at 10, when her father, who had been watching finals of the Scripps National Spelling Bee on ESPN, asked her how to spell the winning word: marocain.
Zaila spelled it perfectly. Then he asked her to spell the winning words going back to 1999. She spelled nearly all of them correctly and was able to tell him the books where she had seen them.
‚ÄúHe was a bit surprised by that,‚Äù Zaila said in an interview before‚Ä¶
articles.title: On Zaila Avant-garde, the New National Spelling Bee Champ

articles.description:
This is a somewhat sentimental post for me: years ago, I had dinner with Jason at a restaurant in Manhattan (I forget which one) and ordered a brandy alexander. It turned out that the bartender didn‚Äôt know how to make one, so I tried my best to explain ‚Äî in the end, I wound up with a white Russian instead. 
But! A brandy alexander is a dang nice drink, and everyone should know how to make one. Even the internet turns up some pretty bizarre recipes that morph into that white Russian I had back in 2016. My favorite (of the ones that I remember) was probably twenty-one years ago, when I was a college student on vacation in Paris, ordered at a piano bar where tourists and locals alike belted out American showtunes. I‚Äôll never be that young again. 
But! It‚Äôs Thursday and it‚Äôs 5:30 on the east c‚Ä¶
articles.title: Brandy Alexander

articles.description:
The Atlantic‚Äôs Ed Yong is one of our great biology writers. He recently won a Pulitzer for his coverage of the COVID-19 pandemic, but it‚Äôs equally illuminating and much more fun to read him write about tapeworms or some other more benign form of life. 
In this case, it‚Äôs about songbirds, which have two unusual things in common besides their love of song: they all evolved to detect and eat sugar in the form of sap and nectar [and did so in a way different from hummingbirds, who also love the sweet stuff], and they all did this in Australia, and from there spread out all over the world.
 Songbirds probably evolved sweet perception about 30 million years ago, when Australia was much wetter. As the climate dried, the soils became poorer and the eucalyptus trees expanded. The forests abounded w‚Ä¶
articles.title: All Songbirds Evolved In Australia (And They Love The Sweet Stuff)

articles.description:
Most US-centric attempts to imagine a future where artists and humanists‚Äô work is better supported by the government hearkens back to the Works Progress Administration (later, the Work Projects Administration) of the late 1930s and early 1940s. There are, however, more recent models outside the US worth emulating, although their stories often don‚Äôt end so well as the WPA‚Äôs appears to.
Until the New Labour movement overhauled the British welfare system in the late 1990s, aspiring musicians were often able to exploit loopholes in the welfare system to support their own work. There‚Äôs some irony in the fact that the more progressive of the two parties winning control of government effectively ended some of the more progressive social programs that thrived under the conservative regime, althoug‚Ä¶
articles.title: New Labour and the End of the Welfare State for Artists

articles.description:
Currently in the United States, an author‚Äôs copyright expires 70 years after the author‚Äôs death or 95 years after its first publication. But what about when an author of a work grants their exclusive copyright to a publisher or some other partnership? In that case, an author can request that the work‚Äôs copyright revert to their sole ownership after 35 years. 
It‚Äôs called reversion, and it doesn‚Äôt happen often, because it‚Äôs not automatic; there are legal hurdles to jump through to file copyright termination notices, meaning you need money, help, and strong motivation to make it happen. And in some famous cases (see virtually every famous superhero ever), if you‚Äôve created something as a work for hire, copyright termination alone isn‚Äôt always going to get it done. But it does happen, and it‚Äô‚Ä¶
articles.title: Who‚Äôs Gotten Their Copyright Back?

articles.description:
Drag has always been a world of aspirations and contradictions, playing not just on gender, but on race, power, wealth, and respectability. So in some sense, it‚Äôs not surprising that being a contestant on RuPaul‚Äôs Drag Race and its affiliated series is remarkably expensive:
‚ÄúI spent more coming into this competition than I did as the down payment on my house,‚Äù Kameron says, her tone serious now.
‚ÄúI spent more on this competition than I did on college,‚Äù Cracker replies solemnly, and a moment of silence falls over both queens. 


Contestants estimate that the cost of all the outfits in a current season of the show is between $20,000 and $30,000. This is five to six times as much as the earlier, more low-budget seasons.
But perhaps this is a case of some well-bankrolled contestants getting ov‚Ä¶
articles.title: It‚Äôs Expensive To Be A Competitive Drag Queen

articles.description:
50 Years of Text Games by Aaron Reed is a favorite newsletter of mine. (It‚Äôs a hard newsletter to read in your email right away, but a rewarding one to pile up and save.) It specializes in in-depth explorations, typically at a single game per newsletter, but also takes a wider view to try to understand why this game at that moment was particularly significant or representative.
Here‚Äôs an example of a great newsletter about a game I do not know well: Graham Nelson‚Äôs Curses, from 1993. Curses, Reed, argues, emerges at an unlikely moment (surrounded by emerging CD-ROM games and exploding console popularity) to bring about an equally unlikely renaissance of interactive fiction.
Curses is scavenger hunt meets Dante‚Äôs Inferno, ‚Äúan allegorical rite of passage,‚Äù adventure game by way of historical‚Ä¶
articles.title: From Text Adventures to Modern Interactive Fiction

articles.description:
The galaxy is wild. Our solar system, with its surprising abundance of living creatures and nonstop radiation and asteroid showers, is a placid, private garden compared to the rest of it. 
In particular, there are perhaps trillions of rogue planets (planetary bodies ranging from little rocky Earth-sized guys to super-Jupiter gas giants) in the Milky Way, including a surprisingly large fleet of the things right near the galactic core.
This is unusual, since the typical way we detect exoplanets is by marking their repeated procession across a star. But rogue planets, by definition, don‚Äôt orbit stars. So the way astronomers find them is a little different, requiring use of gravitational microlensing.
Gizmodo breaks it down:
Data gathered by NASA‚Äôs now-retired Kepler Space Telescope has revealed a small population of free-floating planets near the Galactic Bulge. The new finding raises hope that a pair of upcoming missions will result in further detections of unbound planets, which drift through space separated from their home stars‚Ä¶.
It‚Äôs impossible to know what the conditions are like on these presumed rogue exoplanets, but [astronomer Iain] McDonald said they could be ‚Äúcold, icy wastelands,‚Äù and, if similar in size to Earth, their surfaces would ‚Äúclosely resemble bodies in the outer Solar System, like Pluto.‚Äù
The new paper suggests the presence of a large population of Earth-sized rogue planets in the Milky Way. It‚Äôs becoming clear that free-floating planets are common. McDonald said his team is currently working to come up with a more precise estimate for how many of them might exist.


Did you catch that part about how McDonald‚Äôs team made this discovery using a now-retired telescope? Yeah. Apparently the new telescope projects coming online are both more powerful and (in particular) better equipped to detect gravitational lensing effects, and therefore more likely to detect rogue planets in the future. 
Tags: planets¬†¬† space¬†¬† telescopes
articles.title: There Are Way More Rogue Planets Than We Thought

articles.description:
Fermi‚Äôs paradox is fairly well known: given what we know about the chance of intelligent life appearing somewhere in the universe, why haven‚Äôt any other species to date so far made contact with humanity? You can formalize the paradox via the Drake equation or some other method, but that‚Äôs the crux of it.
What‚Äôs less clear is how Enrico Fermi originally phrased the paradox. At Language Log, Mark Lieberman points out that each of the participants in the original conversation remembers it differently:
At lunch, Fermi suddenly exclaimed, ‚ÄúWhere are they?‚Äù (Teller‚Äôs remembrance), or ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you ever wonder where everybody is?‚Äù (York‚Äôs remembrance), or ‚ÄúBut where is everybody?‚Äù (Konopinski‚Äôs remembrance).
As Liberman writes, ‚Äúour memory of exact word sequences usually fades more quickly than our memory of (contextually interpreted) meanings. More broadly, the exact auditory sensations normally fade very quickly; the corresponding word sequences fade a bit more slowly; and the interpreted meanings last longest.‚Äù 
My own favorite (for purely aesthetic reasons) is ‚Äúwhere is everybody?‚Äù It just kind of says everything you want such an observation to say.
Tags: aliens¬†¬† Enrico Fermi¬†¬† language¬†¬† linguistics¬†¬† paradoxes
articles.title: ‚ÄúWhere Is Everybody?‚Äù or, How Did Fermi Phrase His Paradox?

articles.description:
Beavers are unusual among animals in their ability to radically alter their habitat. They build dams to turn small streams and flood plains into ponds that they use to store food and hide from predators. 
It turns out that this is useful for other species who like to radically alter their habitats, like humans. Let‚Äôs say you‚Äôve got a dried out flood plain in California you want to restore in order to mitigate the effects of a drought, or even to help stop wildfires. Why not hire some beavers? 
The Doty Ravine project cost about $58,000, money that went toward preparing the site for beavers to do their work.
In comparison, a traditional constructed restoration project using heavy equipment across that much land could cost $1 to $2 million, according to Batt‚Ä¶
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs huge when you think about ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Perhaps the Beavers Will Save Us

articles.description:
I have an unusually good memory, especially for symbols, words, and text, but since I don‚Äôt use regular expressions (ahem) regularly, they‚Äôre one of those parts of computer programming and HTML/EPUB editing that I find myself relearning over and over each time I need it. How did something this arcane but powerful even get started? Naturally, its creators were trying to discover (or model) artificial intelligence.
That‚Äôs the crux of this short history of ‚Äúregex‚Äù by Buzz Andersen over at ‚ÄúWhy is this interesting?‚Äù 
 The term itself originated with mathematician Stephen Kleene. In 1943, neuroscientist Warren McCulloch and logician Walter Pitts had just described the first mathematical model of an artificial neuron, and Kleene, who specialized in theories of computation, wanted to investigate ‚Ä¶
articles.title: A History of Regular Expressions and Artificial Intelligence

articles.description:
A new history of late medieval Ethiopia and its interactions with Europe by historian Verena Krebs does something a little unusual, at least for a professor at a European university: it treats the horn of Africa as the center of civilization that it was, and Europeans as the members of far-flung satellite states that Ethiopians could not help but see them as being.
 It‚Äôs not that modern historians of the medieval Mediterranean, Europe and Africa have been ignorant about contacts between Ethiopia and Europe; the issue was that they had the power dynamic reversed. The traditional narrative stressed Ethiopia as weak and in trouble in the face of aggression from external forces, especially the Mamluks in Egypt, so Ethiopia sought military assistance from their fellow Christians to the north‚Äîth‚Ä¶
articles.title: Medieval History with Africa at the Center, Europe at the Margins

articles.description:
It turns out that today (July 5th) is the 50th anniversary of Louis Armstrong‚Äôs final recording, made the night before he passed away in 1971. Armstrong, born August 4th, 1901 (he often told people he was born July 4th, 1900) was a month shy of 70 years old.
50 years ago today, Louis Armstrong made his final reel-to-reel tape. After concluding it with ‚ÄúApril in Paris‚Äù from the ‚ÄúElla and Louis‚Äù album, he went to sleep and passed away. This video contains the final minute of ‚ÄúApril in Paris,‚Äù directly transferred from that last tape. pic.twitter.com/9zq9jWtiPj
‚Äî Louis Armstrong (@ArmstrongHouse) July 5, 2021
   

 Tags: Ella Fitzgerald¬†¬† jazz¬†¬† Louis Armstrong¬†¬† music
articles.title: Louis Armstrong‚Äôs Final Recording

articles.description:
(Hi, this is Tim Carmody filling in for Jason this week. Hope you all have had a lovely holiday and are ready for more bloggy goodness here at kottke dot org.)
For a variety of reasons, I recently found myself inside a legal marijuana dispensary for the first time. I wasn‚Äôt sure exactly what I expected the retail experience to be like ‚Äî a liquor store? a coffee shop? a used car lot? the paraphrenelia shops I first checked out as a teenager? ‚Äî but I was nevertheless surprised. 
The closest analogy I can think of is a jewelry store. There was pretty decent security, including a whole separate room for customers to check in, and everything was presented in a secure display case. A salesperson walked you through the samples to answer questions, guide you in one direction or another, and take y‚Ä¶
articles.title: What Will the Cannabis Industry Look Like In Ten Years?

articles.description:
Olga Khazan writing for The Atlantic:
After an inept coronavirus response, will the United States do better when the next pandemic strikes? Experts generally agree that America learned from the past year, and that the next public-health crisis won‚Äôt be quite as bewildering. But America‚Äôs pandemic preparedness still has major gaps, some of which are too big for any one administration to fix. In recent weeks, I‚Äôve called back many of the experts I interviewed over the past 18 months about masks, testing, contact tracing, quarantine, and more. I asked them, ‚ÄúAre we ready for another one?‚Äù The short answer is ‚ÄúNot quite.‚Äù The long answer is that being truly ‚Äúready‚Äù will be harder than anyone realizes.


The Trump administration mishandled the American response to Covid-19 so completely that it‚Ä¶
articles.title: The US Isn‚Äôt Ready for Another Pandemic

articles.description:
Hermit Nicolas Cage goes on a crusade to find the person who kidnapped his truffle-hunting pig? Yes, please. (This is going to be terrible, right? Or fantastic? No in-between I‚Äôm guessing. Would make an interesting triple feature with The Truffle Hunters .)
Tags: food¬†¬† movies¬†¬† Nicolas Cage¬†¬† Pig¬†¬† trailers¬†¬† video
articles.title: Pig

articles.description:
Bear with me, I am on a bit of an art kick lately. As I said earlier this week, I‚Äôve been slowly working my way through James Payne‚Äôs Great Art Explained video series. But then ‚Äî bang! ‚Äî he came out with a new episode on Vincent van Gogh and his masterpiece, Starry Night. Having seen this painting in person for the first time in a few years just days ago at MoMA, I abandoned the back catalog and dug in to this new one immediately.
Van Gogh is one of my favorites ‚Äî I spent several happy hours at his museum in Amsterdam in 2017 ‚Äî and Payne does a good job of contextualizing his life and work around the time he painted Starry Night, particularly the emphasis on the influence of Japanese art on his work and his probable incorporation of spiral galaxy imagery into Starry Night. Highly recommended, especially if you‚Äôve seen the painting in person.
Tags: art¬†¬† art school¬†¬† James Payne¬†¬† video¬†¬† Vincent van Gogh
articles.title: Great Art Explained: van Gogh‚Äôs Starry Night

articles.description:
ILM visual effects artist Todd Vaziri asked his Twitter followers to share their favorite shots from a movie made in the last decade. The replies are a visual feast (and heavy on blockbusters) ‚Äî here are a few of my favorites.






From top to bottom: Blade Runner 2049, Mad Max: Fury Road, Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse, Widows, Arrival, and Thor: Ragnarok. There are probably several deserving scenes omitted from the thread (no Wes Anderson fans‚Ä¶the sushi scene from Isle of Dogs?), but that Blade Runner shot is probably my favorite from the decade. I would also have included a shot from Dunkirk (one of the expansive plane chase vistas that looked incredible in IMAX) , Portrait of a Lady on Fire, and the final scene in Carol ‚Äî that look gives me chills just writing about it.
Tags: best of¬†¬† movies¬†¬† Todd Vaziri¬†¬† video
articles.title: Some Amazing Shots from the Last Decade of Movies

articles.description:
Evan Puschak looks at how the personal nature, intimacy, and stylistic approachability have given Frida Kahlo‚Äôs work enduring and increasing popularity.
Tags: art¬†¬† art school¬†¬† Evan Puschak¬†¬† Frida Kahlo¬†¬† video

articles.description:
A new iOS app called Brickit has been developed to breathe new life into your old Lego pile. Just dump your bricks out into a pile and the app will analyze what Lego bricks you have, what new creations you can build with them, and provide you with detailed build instructions. It can even guide you to find individual pieces in the pile. View a short demo ‚Äî I‚Äôm assuming they‚Äôre using some sort of AI/machine learning to do this?
My kids have approximately a billion Legos at my house, so I downloaded Brickit to try it out. The process is a little slow and you need to do a little bit of pre-sorting (by taking out the big pieces and spreading your pile out evenly), but watching the app do its thing is kinda magical. When I have more time later, I‚Äôm definitely going to go back and try to build some of the ideas it found for me. (via @marcprecipice)
Tags: artificial intelligence¬†¬† Legos
articles.title: App Helps You Build New Creations from Your Existing Lego Pile

articles.description:
This is an incredible video investigation by the NY Times of the January 6th attack on Congress by terrorists, rioters, and supporters of Donald Trump. They analyzed hundreds of videos, police bodycam footage, and police communications to reconstruct a minute-by-minute account of the Capital breach.

From the accompanying article of six takeaways from the investigation:
Most of the videos we analyzed were filmed by the rioters. By carefully listening to the unfiltered chatter within the crowd, we found a clear feedback loop between President Trump and his supporters.
As Mr. Trump spoke near the White House, supporters who had already gathered at the Capitol building hoping to disrupt the certification responded. Hearing his message to ‚Äúwalk down to the Capitol,‚Äù they interpreted it as the ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Inside the Insurrection on Congress

articles.description:
Professional road racing cyclist Lachlan Morton is attempting to complete the Tour de France this year. Except: He‚Äôs doing it entirely on his own, without teammates, support vehicles, and transportation from the previous day‚Äôs finish to the next day‚Äôs start (which might be dozens or even hundreds of miles apart). That means he‚Äôll be riding an extra 1500 miles, climbing an additional 50,000 feet in elevation, shopping for his own meals, and still trying to beat the peloton to Paris. Here‚Äôs a quick explanatory trailer:

You can follow his progress on Rapha‚Äôs site and check out updates in this Instagram Story. He‚Äôs currently ahead of the peloton, even riding day four in Birkenstocks:
Ah, but ‚Äî the day three press release had an ominous note in it. Right after telling us that Morton had ‚Äúpicked up a tub of couscous and a couple of bags of nuts for dinner‚Äù came the real kicker: our protagonist had a bad knee, and had bought new pedals to allow a switch to flat shoes. 
So on day four, Morton set off with his new pedals and covered both stage four and stage five of the actual Tour de France ‚Äî in a pair of Birkenstocks. Despite his sensible sandals, Morton managed to average the same speeds as the day prior, getting through the time trial in 1:17.



(via matt)
Tags: cycling¬†¬† Lachlan Morton¬†¬† sports¬†¬† Tour de France¬†¬† video

Last week I posted about the digital ‚Äúrestoration‚Äù of Rembrandt‚Äôs The Night Watch with the help of an AI program.
Using a contemporary copy of the full scene painted by Gerrit Lundens and an AI program for getting the colors and angles right, the Rijksmuseum has ‚Äúrestored‚Äù The Night Watch, augmenting the painting with digital printouts of the missing bits.


Edith Zimmerman got access to this technology and ran some of her own experiments of famous artworks. You may be shocked and delighted at what she found.

Tags: art¬†¬† Edith Zimmerman¬†¬† Rembrandt¬†¬† remix
articles.title: American Gothic + 1 and Other Restored Masterpieces

articles.description:
Over the past several months, I‚Äôve read several pieces about the possible origins of SARS-CoV-2 and have been frustrated with the certainty with which folks who should know better have embraced the ‚Äúlab leak hypothesis‚Äù. So, I was happy to see Zeynep Tufekci‚Äôs characteristically even-handed and comprehensive overview of the evidence about the virus‚Äôs origins in the NY Times.
While the Chinese government‚Äôs obstruction may keep us from knowing for sure whether the virus, SARS-CoV-2, came from the wild directly or through a lab in Wuhan or if genetic experimentation was involved, what we know already is troubling.
Years of research on the dangers of coronaviruses, and the broader history of lab accidents and errors around the world, provided scientists with plenty of reasons to proceed with caution as they investigated this class of pathogens. But troubling safety practices persisted.
Worse, researchers‚Äô success at uncovering new threats did not always translate into preparedness.
Even if the coronavirus jumped from animal to human without the involvement of research activities, the groundwork for a potential disaster had been laid for years, and learning its lessons is essential to preventing others.


Is it possible that SARS-CoV-2 came from a lab? Yes. Is it probable? We can‚Äôt know that right now. It‚Äôs a tantalizing puzzle involving a possible cover-up, but irresponsibly assigning certainty to the situation does no one but attention-seeking pundits any good.
Tags: Covid-19¬†¬† medicine¬†¬† science¬†¬† Zeynep Tufekci
articles.title: Where Did SARS-CoV-2 Come From?

articles.description:
This is a filmstrip version of Margaret Wise Brown‚Äôs Goodnight Moon produced in 1984. Not sure what a filmstrip is? Boing Boing explains:
From the 1940s until the low-cost videocassette boom of the 1980s, audio filmstrips were commonly used in classrooms as an alternative to 16mm film projectors that were more expensive and fiddly to keep working.


This post doubles as one of those ‚Äúsay how old you are without saying how old you are‚Äù Twitter prompts. Here‚Äôs more on filmstrips from the Museum of Applied Arts & Sciences:
While the show was a welcome diversion from parsing, long division and dictation, what we didn‚Äôt realise was the filmstrips were an educational revolution in Australia akin to smart boards today. They were stored in neat little canisters which could be easily dispatched to schools. Accompanying them was a script read by the teacher describing the 25 or so images depicted in the films, which were manually advanced in the projector.


Until watching this Goodnight Moon video, I had totally forgotten about the beep used in filmstrip audio used to signal someone to switch to the next frame.
Tags: books¬†¬† Goodnight Moon¬†¬† Margaret Wise Brown¬†¬† video
articles.title: Goodnight Moon Filmstrip (1984)

articles.description:
In 1715, a significant chunk of Rembrandt‚Äôs masterpiece The Night Watch, including a 2-foot-wide swath from the left side of the painting, was lopped off in order to fit the painting in a smaller space. (WTF?!) Using a contemporary copy of the full scene painted by Gerrit Lundens and an AI program for getting the colors and angles right, the Rijksmuseum has ‚Äúrestored‚Äù The Night Watch, augmenting the painting with digital printouts of the missing bits. The uncropped Rembrandt is shown above and here is Lundens‚Äôs version:

I‚Äôm not an expert on art, but the 1715 crop and the shift of the principal characters from right-of-center to the center appears to have radically altered the whole feel of the painting.
With the addition especially on the left and the bottom, an empty space is created in the painting where they march towards. When the painting was cut [the lieutenants] were in the centre, but Rembrandt intended them to be off-centre marching towards that empty space, and that is the genius that Rembrandt understands: you create movement, a dynamic of the troops marching towards the left of the painting.


(via @john_overholt)
Tags: art¬†¬† artificial intelligence¬†¬† Gerrit Lundens¬†¬† Rembrandt
articles.title: A Rembrandt Masterpiece Uncropped by AI

articles.description:
In just over two hours, this video presents 1540 paintings by impressionist master Claude Monet, a significant portion of his lifetime output. This is a really intriguing way to look at art. It‚Äôs not in-person and you don‚Äôt get a lot of time with each piece, but the video is HD, you can pause or slow the playback speed, and by seeing a lot of work over a short span of time, you can get a real sense of the stylistic choices and variations across Monet‚Äôs oeuvre ‚Äî a view of the forest rather than the trees. (via open culture)
Tags: art¬†¬† Claude Monet¬†¬† video
articles.title: See 1540 Paintings by Claude Monet in Two Hours

articles.description:
The US Postal Service has released a set of Sun Science stamps that use images from NASA‚Äôs Solar Dynamics Observatory to illustrate different solar phenomena like plasma blasts, sunspots, and solar flares.
Printed with a foil treatment that adds a glimmer to the stamps, the images on these stamps come from NASA‚Äôs Solar Dynamics Observatory, a spacecraft launched in February 2010 to keep a constant watch on the sun from geosynchronous orbit above Earth. The striking colors in these images do not represent the actual colors of the sun as perceived by human eyesight. Instead, each image is colorized by NASA according to different wavelengths that reveal or highlight specific features of the sun‚Äôs activity.
One of the stamps highlights sunspots, two feature images of coronal holes, two show coronal loops, two depict plasma blasts, one is a view of an active sun that emphasizes its magnetic fields, and two show different views of a solar flare.


NASA has more on the science behind the images on the stamps and the whole set of stamps are available for purchase online.
See also A Decade of the Sun.
Tags: astronomy¬†¬† design¬†¬† NASA¬†¬† science¬†¬† stamps¬†¬† Sun¬†¬† USPS
articles.title: New USPS Stamps Celebrate the Sun

articles.description:
Sometimes you run across an aspect of reality and it just completely blows your mind. You‚Äôve heard of dark matter, right? Well, meet dark fish: biologists suspect that up to 95% of the world‚Äôs total fish population lives in a deep layer of the ocean that is difficult to detect and we know little about.
An international team of marine biologists has found mesopelagic fish in the earth‚Äôs oceans constitute 10 to 30 times more biomass than previously thought.
UWA Professor Carlos Duarte says mesopelagic fish ‚Äî fish that live between 100 and 1000m below the surface ‚Äî must therefore constitute 95 per cent of the world‚Äôs fish biomass.
‚ÄúBecause the stock is much larger it means this layer must play a more significant role in the functioning of the ocean and affecting the flow of carbon and oxygen in the ocean,‚Äù he says.


See also this thread from ocean scientist Andrew Thaler:
There‚Äôs a globe-spanning layer of mesopelagic fish that is so dense it distorts SONAR. For decades we had no idea what created the Deep Scattering Layer or why it moved. We still know almost nothing about it.


It‚Äôs astounding how much we don‚Äôt know about the ocean:
There‚Äôs an entire family of whales with at least 22 species that we know almost nothing about.


We know way more about stars that are billions of light years away than about some parts of the ocean a few hundred feet below the surface of our own planet.
See also dark fungi: ‚ÄúBy one estimate, there are between 2.2 million and 3.8 million species of fungi ‚Äî and more than 90% of them aren‚Äôt cataloged.‚Äù. (via @_zeets & @chadmumm)
Tags: Andrew Thaler¬†¬† fish¬†¬† science
articles.title: Dark Fish

articles.description:
This short documentary takes a look at the Black surfing community in the Rockaways. These surfers are members of the Black Surfing Association (East Coast branch), which Surfer magazine profiled last summer:
‚ÄúWhen you talk to kids here at Rockaway, they think of a surfer as John John Florence ‚Äî blonde,‚Äù says Harris. ‚ÄúWhen I say, ‚ÄòHey, I‚Äôm a surfer,‚Äô they‚Äôre shocked. We‚Äôre trying to reach every kid, but we‚Äôre really trying to reach the kids that wouldn‚Äôt otherwise get the opportunity.
We just want to keep kids busy and active, and spread the message and spread the stoke of surfing, and go into schools and talk to kids about water safety.‚Äù
‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no racism out there‚Äù, says Harris of the ocean. ‚ÄúWhen you come out of that water, of course you go back to your life. But you lose yourself when you get into the waves.‚Äù


 Tags: NYC¬†¬† surfing¬†¬† video

articles.description:
Stevie Wonder. Mahalia Jackson. Nina Simone. Gladys Knight & the Pips. B.B. King. Sly and the Family Stone. Over six weeks in the summer of 1969, all of these legendary artists (and more!) performed at the Harlem Cultural Festival in NYC, drawing an estimated 300,000 people. The festival was filmed and broadcast on a local TV station, but the footage was never commercially released and so unlike that other 1969 festival, this event largely slipped from public memory.
Now, the Harlem Cultural Festival finally gets its due in the form of Summer of Soul, a forthcoming documentary directed by Questlove that uses that old footage to great effect. I‚Äôve heard nothing but good things about this movie ‚Äî it won both the Grand Jury Prize and the Audience Award at the Sundance Film Festival earlier this year. Summer of Soul is out in theaters and on Hulu July 2.
Tags: movies¬†¬† music¬†¬† NYC¬†¬† Questlove¬†¬† Summer of Soul¬†¬† trailers¬†¬† video
articles.title: Summer of Soul

articles.description:
From Electric Vehicles Won‚Äôt Save Us by Coby Lefkowitz:
This isn‚Äôt a story about Elon Musk, or Tesla, or a contrarian take about how ‚Äúoil is good, actually.‚Äù I unconditionally support electric vehicles in their quest to take over the primacy of gasoline-powered vehicles in the market. But I don‚Äôt save that enthusiasm for their prospects on society broadly. From the perspective of the built environment, there is nothing functionally different between an electric vehicle and a gasoline propelled one. The relationship is the same, and it‚Äôs unequivocally destructive. Cars, however they‚Äôre powered, are environmentally cataclysmic, break the tethers of community, and force an infrastructure of dependency that is as financially ruinous to our country as it is dangerous to us as people. In order to build a more sustainable future and a better world for humanity, we need to address the root problems that have brought us to where we so perilously lie today.


 Tags: cars¬†¬† cities¬†¬† Coby Lefkowitz¬†¬† global warming¬†¬† USA
articles.title: EVs Won‚Äôt Save Us from Our Car Culture‚Äôs Ill Effects

articles.description:
Clinton Jones challenged his community of 3D artists to interpret a simple animation of a person walking with a heavy load. 2400 people participated and Jones collected the 100 renders for this video. What a fantastic illustration of the power of constraints and the abundance of human creativity. Ok, much of the imagery is borrowed from Star Wars and other sci-fi universes, but the stuff that isn‚Äôt is delightful. Even with no explicit narrative connection between the scenes, somehow this all seems like part of one big journey. One of the simplest stories we tell is someone moving from one place to another and it doesn‚Äôt need to be The Odyssey, Fury Road, or Thelma & Louise to be compelling.
You can also watch a video featuring all 2400 entries (it‚Äôs 2h 45m long) and a montage from a previous challenge featuring 125 artists.
See also Transfiguration: An Ever-Evolving Walking Figure. (via waxy)
Tags: 3D¬†¬† Clinton Jones¬†¬† video
articles.title: 100 3D Artists Interpret the Same Scene of a Walking Person

articles.description:
Well, this is cool: a recently discovered minor planet estimated to be between 62 and 230 miles across is currently journeying through our solar system and sometime in 2031 will be almost as close to the Sun as Saturn.
And it turns out, astronomers are about to witness the closest pass of this incredible round trip. Currently, 2014 UN271 is about 22 Astronomical Units (AU) from the Sun (for reference, Earth is 1 AU from the Sun). That means it‚Äôs already closer than Neptune, at 29.7 AU. And it‚Äôs not stopping there ‚Äî it‚Äôs already traveled 7 AU in the last seven years, and at its closest in 2031, it‚Äôs expected to pass within 10.9 AU of the Sun, almost reaching the orbit of Saturn.
Before then, it‚Äôs expected to develop the characteristic coma and tail of a comet, as icy material on its surface vaporizes from the heat of the Sun. This close pass would give astronomers an unprecedented close look at Oort cloud objects.


C‚Äômon NASA, let‚Äôs a get a probe fired up and visit this very unusual object!
Tags: astronomy¬†¬† science¬†¬† space
articles.title: Unexpected Minor Planet to Visit the Inner Solar System Soon

articles.description:
In a TEDx Talk from 2017, LB Hannahs talks about their experience as a transgender dad, comfort vs authenticity, and the collision of theoretical gender roles & identities with the practicalities of parenthood.
Now, for most people, what their child will call them is not something that they give much thought to outside of culturally specific words or variations on a gendered theme like ‚Äúmama,‚Äù ‚Äúmommy,‚Äù or ‚Äúdaddy,‚Äù ‚Äúpapa.‚Äù But for me, the possibility is what this child, who will grow to be a teenager and then a real-life adult, will call me for the rest of our lives, was both extremely scary and exciting. And I spent nine months wrestling with the reality that being called ‚Äúmama‚Äù or something like it didn‚Äôt feel like me at all. And no matter how many times or versions of ‚Äúmom‚Äù I tried, it always felt forced and deeply uncomfortable. I knew being called ‚Äúmom‚Äù or ‚Äúmommy‚Äù would be easier to digest for most people. The idea of having two moms is not super novel, especially where we live. 
So I tried other words. And when I played around with ‚Äúdaddy,‚Äù it felt better. Better, but not perfect. It felt like a pair of shoes that you really liked but you needed to wear and break in. And I knew the idea of being a female-born person being called ‚Äúdaddy‚Äù was going to be a harder road with a lot more uncomfortable moments. But, before I knew it, the time had come and Elliot came screaming into the world, like most babies do, and my new identity as a parent began. I decided on becoming a daddy, and our new family faced the world.


(thx, megan)
Tags: gender¬†¬† LB Hannahs¬†¬† LGBT¬†¬† parenting¬†¬† video
articles.title: What It‚Äôs Like to Be a Transgender Dad

articles.description:
Production designers working on science fiction movies and TV shows are part-time magicians because they routinely have to invent the future using things from the present. The site Star Trek + Design is collecting the futuristic design objects ‚Äî chairs, cups, silverware, sofas ‚Äî that designers used on the sets of Star Trek movies and TV shows to depict the future.
Being drawn to the aesthetics of Trek, especially of The Next Generation, made me curious about the specific objects that set designers used to create the visual embodiment of what living and working on a starship would look like in a technologically-advanced, post-scarcity future.


For instance, this is an RBT Chair by Teknion used in Star Trek: Discovery:

Park Avenue glasses made by Anchor Hocking were used for barware in TNG:

Voyager used Arne Jacobsen‚Äôs AJ Flatware in several episodes (as did Kubrick‚Äôs 2001):

Check out the site for many more sourced objects.
See also Film and Furniture, a Site About the Decor in Movies.
Tags: design¬†¬† movies¬†¬† Star Trek¬†¬† TV
articles.title: Sourcing Design Objects Used in Star Trek

Chuck just needs to admit that he wants sugar in his tea
 Madeline Campbell joins Steve to discuss the upcoming Seattle Kraken Expansion Draft, the 2021 NHL Entry Draft, potential Philadelphia Flyers trades, the Stanley Cup getting dinged up by the Tampa Bay Lightning, and Mare of Easttown accents.
Make sure to follow us on twitter @Flyperbole and @madelinecampbll. Also, follow @BSH_Radio and don‚Äôt forget to rate us on iTunes! You can find the entire Broad Street Hockey audio offerings in the following places: iTunes, Stitcher, Google Podcasts, Spotify, and RSS.
articles.title: Flyperbole: Double draft week

articles.description:
Photo by Derek Leung/Getty Images
    

  
As we near the draft, it‚Äôs time to take a look at the other goalie prospect likely to be taken in the first round.
 Today, in continuation of our community draft board series, we‚Äôll be taking a look at Sebastian Cossa. The towering netminder has flashed plenty of promise in the WHL with the Edmonton Oil Kings, intriguing scouts with his blend of respectable athleticism, ideal frame, and cerebral approach to the position.
Cossa put up impressive stats with one of the WHL‚Äôs best teams in 2020-21, and is arguably the biggest reason behind Edmonton‚Äôs first place finish. The 6‚Äô6‚Äù tendy went 17-1-1 with a 1.57 GAA and .941 SV% in 19 games this season, putting him in league with some of the best goalie prospects to come out of the WHL in recent memory (t‚Ä¶
articles.title: BSH 2021 Community Draft Board, No. 27: Sebastian Cossa

articles.description:
Kyle Ross-USA TODAY Sports
    

  
In which the gang preps for silly season to the max.
 It‚Äôs the show before the Expansion Draft and the gang gets into all the ways in ways in which the next two weeks will, probably, be absolutely bonkers for all of us.
articles.title: BSH Radio #314: It‚Äôs go time

articles.description:
Photo by Len Redkoles/NHLI via Getty Images
    

  
Today‚Äôs open discussion thread, complete with your daily dose of Flyers news and notes‚Ä¶  
 *Well folks, today is the final day before next Wednesday‚Äôs expansion draft the Chuck and the rest of his NHL GM pals can make any moves, so perhaps something will happen. Otherwise, we wait til next week. And hope that Chuck is reflecting on what happened in the Vegas draft. [ProHockeyTalk]
*The Vegas expansion was a long time coming for the league, and the way they handled the organization‚Äôs entry into the game set a new benchmark for expansion going forward. Including, obviously, Seattle. [Yahoo Sports]
*We‚Äôre pack to the Q for pick number 26 in the BSH Community Draft. [BSH]
*The idea of Gabriel Landeskog leaving the Avalanche ‚Äî or the Avalanche letting him walk ‚Äî seems ridiculous. At the moment, though? Not impossible. [Mile High Hockey]
*We are all chomping at the bit for Chuck to make a move, for good reason, but the Edmonton Oilers made the first move this offseason and they got absolutely robbed. So, sometimes, patience works in your favor. [TSN]
*And finally, here‚Äôs so good reading on a Friday morning: 25 players most likely to be traded this offseason. Some names you may not have expected on there. [The Athletic]
*Finally finally, another good thing on a Friday morning? New BSH Radio:
articles.title: Friday Morning Fly By: The calm before the crazy

articles.description:
To the Q once more!
 We‚Äôre nearing the home stretch here folks, and would you look at that! We‚Äôre heading back to the QMJHL for the third time this week!
Next up on the draft board is Xavier Bourgault, who, because of his early birthday, has just wrapped up his third season in the QMJHL, and it was quite a productive one at that! Putting up a cool 40 points in 29 games, Bourgault came in third in scoring on his team, and flashed a very intriguing offensive toolkit in the process. 
As was the case with Zachary Bolduc when we talked about him a few days ago, Bourgault is a natural center who has spent much of his QMJHL career playing on the wing. This makes his projection a little trickier, but hey, we could also spin that a little more positively as just being positional flexibility. Sure? ‚Ä¶
articles.title: BSH 2021 Community Draft Board, No. 26: Xavier Bourgault

articles.description:
Photo by Elsa/Getty Images
    

  
Today‚Äôs open discussion thread, complete with your daily dose of Flyers news and notes‚Ä¶  
 *Chuck‚Äôs presser the other day, remember that? Meltzer pulled out the important bits in case you needed Spark Notes. [Flyers]
*And to really break it down, brilliantly of course, is Charlie over at The Athletic. He puts the whole thing into words we can all understand. [The Athletic]
*We are now less than a week away from the expansion draft, so here‚Äôs a little primer, or a little refresher, depending on where you are in your journey. [Inquirer]
*The SB Nation mock draft has been going on these last couple of weeks and when it came time for Broad Street Hockey to put on their Chuck Fletcher hats and make a pick? We did the damn thing. [BSH]
*Speaking of mock drafts, the Community Draft Board is reaching the end of the first round, and for the 25th overall you folks took things to Sweden. [BSH]
*As we‚Äôve seen over the last few days, the approach to improvement some NHL GMs are taking to kick off the summer is to move on from the past. [ProHockeyTalk]
*Speaking of moving on, maybe Seattle will take Robert Hagg? [BSH]
*Vladimir Tarasenko has a ten-team trade list and your Flyers are on it. [BSH]
*With the draft getting so close, it‚Äôs possible player trades are going to have to get going just so teams are well-situated when Ron Francis comes knocking. [Sports Illustrated]
*If you‚Äôre new to the game or just want to try and learn a little more about what the nerds are talking about, these stats primers are always a big help. It‚Äôs always fun to learn something, gain some new perspectives, these kinds of things. [Winging It In Motown]
*The Minnesota Wild got a dog. GET A DOG, THE FLYERS!! [Hockey Wilderness]
*And finally, it‚Äôs been a long year and we‚Äôve been dying to do this... the Broad Street Hockey Draft Party is BACK. Details here and on today‚Äôs BSH Radio later this afternoon. It‚Äôll be so much fun to be in a room full of Flyers fans having fun together. Come if you can! [BSH]
articles.title: Thursday Morning Fly By: Party on

articles.description:
Photo by Len Redkoles/NHLI via Getty Images
    

  
The disgruntled St. Louis Blues winger would approve of a trade to Philadelphia.
 After the St. Louis Blues won the Stanley Cup in 2019, they have been waddling their way into mediocrity and a grander sense of non-existence in the larger scope of the NHL. They did the thing and it was nice and emotional, but since then it‚Äôs been just shedding some contracts and trying to stay at least somewhat competitive with the talent they have locked up there.
Most recently, former All-Star winger Vladimir Tarasenko wants his way out of St. Louis and it‚Äôs no secret ‚Äî like, at all. He has gone through some hellish injuries and just wants a brand new start in a new organization that isn‚Äôt riddled with some medical complaints, like requiring to do a sec‚Ä¶
articles.title: Flyers reportedly on Tarasenko‚Äôs trade list

articles.description:
Photo by Len Redkoles/NHLI via Getty Images
    

  
In our first event since 2019, we celebrate.
 Covid can‚Äôt stop us! Ok, yes it can, and it did, but we‚Äôre back with another Broad Street Hockey event! We are hosting our 2021 NHL Entry Draft Party at Xfinity Live ‚Äî specifically Bullies Pub ‚Äî on Friday July 23rd beginning at 6pm.
The reason we selected Bullies is obviously because of the strong Flyers connection, but also because they have both indoor and outdoor spaces for those who aren‚Äôt comfortable with indoor events. We are expecting a few hundred people, so please keep that in mind if you are unvaccinated or uncomfortable with groups. We will follow all of the Philadelphia guidelines for safety, please review them here, and encourage you to wear a mask.
There is a Phillies game at Citizens Bank Park on the same evening, so if you are driving, you will have to pay for parking until 8:05pm. If you are taking public transportation, factor crowds into your timing. 
Xfinitylive.com
  
The kitchens will not be open within Bullies Pub, but Xfinity Live does offer Chickies & Petes, Geno‚Äôs, and Lorenzo‚Äôs stalls and those will be available to us. 
Whether you like the Flyers right now or not, whether they actually make the pick at 13 or not, we will be there. This is the first opportunity since Festivus in 2019 for us to all get together and boo the commissioner and maybe Chuck Fletcher too. You don‚Äôt even have to be a Flyers fan to attend! We accept all boos from all fans.
When: Friday July 23, beginning at 6pm
Where: Bullies Pub inside Xfinity Live
Who: Broad Street Hockey fans and friends
We‚Äôre really looking forward to seeing you all, even in this uninspiring draft year and with this mediocre team.
articles.title: Broad Street Hockey 2021 NHL Entry Draft party!

articles.description:
Moving to the SHL to look at a solid power forward.
 Today, we move away from the QMJHL, and across the ocean to Sweden where we‚Äôll take a look at another European prospect. Simon Robertsson is a big bodied RW (6‚Äô0‚Äù, 190 lbs) who uses his strength to his advantage well in all three zones, and has one of the hardest shots in the entire draft. He‚Äôs played well at the U20 level, scoring 50 points in 56 games across the last two seasons at that level. Therefore, naturally, he was called up beginning in 2019-20 to the SHL club, where he hasn‚Äôt been able to replicate the success he found before, but not everyone can succeed against men right away.
Though, Robertsson‚Äôs fundamentals were solid regardless, and all signs point to him being able to break through in 2021-22. 
BSH 2021 Community Draft ‚Ä¶
articles.title: BSH 2021 Community Draft Board, No. 25: Simon Robertsson

articles.description:
Photo by Elsa/Getty Images
    

  
The 26-year-old has his fans and detractors, but he‚Äôs a cost effective option for the Kraken given his ability.
 Our look at possible targets for the Seattle Kraken in this month‚Äôs expansion draft began with James van Riemsdyk, continued with a defensive option in Shayne Gostisbehere, and today chugs along by dissecting a significantly less costly option for the NHL‚Äôs newest club. 


Robert Hagg
2021 Statistical Overview: 2 G, 3 A in 34 GP | 15.40 TOI/G | 46.20 5-on-5 xGF%
Contract: Signed through 2021-22 at $1,600,000 per year
Current Player Evaluation
The 26-year-old former second-round pick (41st overall in 2013) is rather an easy current evaluation. 
His possession metrics at 5-on-5 have never been very strong compared to his teammates ‚Äî he‚Äôs lagged ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Aspiring Krakens: Robert Hagg

articles.description:
Photo by Harry How/Getty Images
    

  
Why use a first-round draft pick when you can just simply have Matt Dumba instead?
 With the No. 13 pick of the annual SB Nation NHL Mock Draft, the Philadelphia Flyers select...
Nobody!
Because they traded their first-round pick, along with prospect Elliot Desnoyers, to the Minnesota Wild for defenseman Matt Dumba! Surprise!
It‚Äôs no secret that the Flyers desperately need to improve defensively this offseason. And while another year of experience could be what some of their young blueliners need, this isn‚Äôt the offseason to take a ‚Äúwait and see‚Äù approach. The Flyers need immediate improvements from their defensemen, and the best way to help accelerate that process is by acquiring a veteran NHLer with a proven track record of success.
Dumba certainl‚Ä¶
articles.title: NHL Mock Draft 2021: Flyers acquire Matt Dumba from Wild for first-round pick, Elliot Desnoyers

Today‚Äôs open discussion thread, complete with your daily dose of Flyers news and notes‚Ä¶  
 *Chuck Fletcher and the Flyers called a press conference yesterday to talk about... well, nothing, really. Talked a bit about the expansion draft, vaguely. [Inquirer]

articles.title: Wednesday Morning Fly By: No news is no news

articles.description:
Photo by Mathieu Belanger/Getty Images

Young teenage hockey players were either left with no league to play in, a delayed season, or a season that was full of pauses due to quarantines and outbreaks ‚Äî not the best experiences for players trying to impress NHL scouts enough to be selected this July. articles.description:
Photo by Len Redkoles/NHLI via Getty Images
    

  
The Arizona Coyotes are selling everything and the Flyers should be in on it.
 The Philadelphia Flyers should do as much as possible to overcome any shortcomings from last season. Self-destructive goaltending aside, the Flyers were an alright team up top and a miserable catastrophe on the blue line.
But truly, why not solve any problems you have by getting a really, really good forward that can make life easier on everyone wearing the same uniform on the ice? We‚Äôre creeping towards position-less hockey anyway, so getting someone that will no doubt make your team better, no matter the area they most commonly exist in on the ice, is the way to go.
Especially when a team is essentially selling anything that isn‚Äôt bolted to the desert floor.‚Ä¶
articles.title: May I interest you in a small boy?

articles.description:
Photo by Mike Stobe/NHLI via Getty Images
    

  
An undersized winger who can fill up the net? Sounds like a guy to pass out for sure.
 After another dip into the defensive pool we‚Äôve got a stone cold sniper on our hands in record-setting Matthew Coronato out of the USHL and the Chicago Steel. The Harvard commit set Steel team records for scoring at a blazing pace last year and earned the nickname ‚Äúthe Bison‚Äù for crashing the net and showing no fear going into the high-danger areas to score. 
Sweet.

articles.description:
Photo by Elsa/Getty Images
    

  
With Montreal unexpectedly in the Stanley Cup Final, can we see Philadelphia do something similar?
 Every fan base wants to be part of one and it‚Äôs human nature to want to cheer for one. It‚Äôs the age-old tale of an underdog. All the odds are against them in the trivial fight to be declared the champion, but they go on to win it all (or get close) in a monumental and emotional and compelling series of games that can last them through a handful of seasons ‚Äî no matter what their management decides to do or who they trade away.
It is something that is so cherished and talked about even from neutral observers of any sport, just something so incredible and captivating that can be discussed beyond the normal fanatic circles.
With the Montreal Canadiens steeped ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Can the Flyers go on a Canadiens-esque playoff run?

articles.description:
Heather Barry - All Rights Reserved
    

  
Now that‚Äôs a Sunday Funday.
 Sunday afternoon, the Flyers Warriors Hockey took on the Flyers Alumni in Aston, PA at Ice Works, honoring Joe Watson for the Alumni Warriors Showcase. 
There was lots of smiles and surprises throughout the afternoon: a Gritty arrival, a proposal, custom Warriors third jersey reveals, and lots of wigs.
Ways you can support the Philadelphia Flyers Warriors program to give disabled veterans a chance to play a sport, bond, and form lifelong friendships and even a new life - follow their social pages! Venmo link for donations and merchandise are all located on their Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/FlyersWarriorHockey/

articles.description:
Photo by Mark LoMoglio/Icon Sportswire via Getty Images
    

  
Who you got?
 It‚Äôs the end of the line, folks! We‚Äôve finally arrived at the Cup Final! We expected that these playoffs were going to be weird, and boy did they ever deliver. Three rounds later and we‚Äôre staring down a matchup between the Tampa Bay Lightning... and the Montreal Canadiens. Sure, why not. 
And how‚Äôs this one going to shake out? Can Tampa win back to back cups? Or will Montreal continue their run through some of the league‚Äôs most stacked teams? Our staff‚Äôs back to weigh in. 
Tampa Bay Lightning vs. Montreal Canadiens
Maddie: I don‚Äôt really know which outcome I‚Äôm rooting for here, but I think Tampa‚Äôs going to come out with the win here. Montreal‚Äôs run has been pretty remarkable, and I do think they‚Äôre going to mak‚Ä¶

Photo by Christopher Mast/Getty Images
    

  
The mobile defender has seen his draft stock slide in the past year, to the point of possible overcorrection.
 Every year, there‚Äôs a prospect whose standing within the scouting community takes an unforeseen hit; this is sometimes deserved, but in other cases a product of circumstance. Often there are draft-eligible players who fall below lofty expectations, yet become solid or better NHL players. Carson Lambos falls squarely within the crosshairs of this characterization after what could be considered a disappointing 2020-21 campaign.
It was a chaotic year for all the players in this draft, but perhaps Lambos had the roughest time among the high-profile ones. After a brief, yet alarming run in Finland‚Äôs Liiga, U18 and U20 leagues, Lambos retu‚Ä¶
articles.title: BSH 2021 Community Draft Board, No. 15: Carson Lambos

Some offense coming from Sweden might be available.
 If there is just one young prospect that most casual and not-so-casual draft fanatics will be jumping for joy if their team snags him in the mid-to-late first round, it would be Fabian Lysell.
After a year bouncing between the Swedish junior league and the Swedish Hockey League, Lysell found himself of a Lule√• HF team full of former NHL players (most notably former Philadelphia Flyer Erik Gustafsson, the other one) and a couple NHL Draft hopefuls. Due to the older, more experienced roster, the teenager wasn‚Äôt able to get a ton of ice-time and that can certainly explain his low point totals. Averaging just over seven minutes a game, Lysell was just there for the exper‚Ä¶
articles.title: BSH 2021 Community Draft Board, No. 14: Fabian Lysell

articles.description:
Photo by Dave Sandford/NHLI via Getty Images
    

  
Your job is not to be nice, it‚Äôs to win championships and to entertain.
 The National Hockey League has a boring offseason relative to every other major professional sports league, and it‚Äôs time for that to be addressed. For entirely too long, the rules and construction of the league have been based upon what makes a general manager‚Äôs job easier, more comfortable, and as close to failure-proof as possible. The lack of player mobility via the current restricted free agency system is the epitome of the flaws within the structure of the league‚Äôs approach to fan engagement, and it‚Äôs largely because GMs care more about playing nice with one another and keeping everyone employed than they do about winning. That needs to change for the sake of‚Ä¶
articles.title: The NHL has a cowardice problem, and it needs to be addressed

In which Dave Hakstol ruins the show, AGAIN.¬†
 Friends, Dave Hakstol was hired as the head coach of the Seattle Kraken while we recorded. Need we say more?

Photo by Bruce Bennett/Getty Images
    

  
It‚Äôs all about looks.
 I am going to made it really clear, before anything else is said, that I am not a professional scout, or even someone that evaluates hockey players on a serious level. I wouldn‚Äôt take my opinion of a player and run with it, making it the concrete fact or something to base your opinion on. Even still, there‚Äôs a clear problem with how people and those people that are in power to make organizational decisions, evaluate and judge hockey players on the ice.
Everyone has experienced this before. Whether you‚Äôre at school or at your mind-numbingly desolate desk job, there are moments where your superior comes around and you panic. Your heart starts racing because you simply do not have anything to do. Maybe you have already finish‚Ä¶
articles.title: There‚Äôs a problem in how we judge NHL players

The Kraken found their guy, apparently!
 Former Flyers head coach Dave Hakstol is getting a second chance as an NHL team‚Äôs bench boss, and it‚Äôs with the Seattle Kraken.
SEATTLE, WE GOT OUR GUY!

Get to know our new bench boss ‚Üí https://t.co/uiBhw09CfE pic.twitter.com/fe9p7Hry64

There were several names being thrown around as potential candidates to become Seattle‚Äôs first-ever head coach ‚Äî Rick Tocchet, Bruce Boudreau and Tony Granato among them. articles.description:
Getty Images
    

  
The ultra-offensive forward is next on our board.
 Chaz Lucius can potentially be a mid-first round steal. The electric forward missed a significant amount of time due to multiple injuries ‚Äî whether it was recovering from surgery or getting sick before the Under-18 Worlds ‚Äî but when he was healthy, he put on a clinic on how to score heaps and piles and heaps of goals.
A mid-sized center that just gets to the front of his opponent‚Äôs net and makes their goaltender have a miserable time, he is able to get his shots off in that dangerous area and just simply produces from that spot on the ice. Every team needs to have a pigeon and Lucius can potentially be one of the best at the top level at shoveling pucks into the back of the net.
He‚Äôs a unique player and one that will ‚Ä¶
articles.title: BSH 2021 Community Draft Board, No. 13: Chaz Lucius

articles.description:
Photo by Bruce Bennett/Getty Images
    

  
Could the Flyers lose one of their most productive forwards from 2021 in the expansion draft?
 As the Flyers prepare for the offseason to get busy, they are now officially less than a month away from the summer‚Äôs first major off-ice event: the Seattle Kraken‚Äôs Expansion Draft. Set to take place on July 21, the NHL‚Äôs 32nd team will select its initial roster like Vegas did four years earlier.
For an initial read on the rules for Seattle‚Äôs draft, and how the Flyers should be prepared to handle it, you can read this from March of last year. Shockingly little has changed in terms of the Flyers‚Äô expansion outlook since then, other than the fact that Scott Laughton‚Äôs contract extension makes him a likely protected piece for the Flyers and as such takes‚Ä¶

 Steph joins Steve to discuss Corey Perry‚Äôs deal with the Devil, the Philadelphia Flyers‚Äô goal song, defensive trade targets, cryptids, Cole Beasley, Carl Nassib, bird wars, Sixers disappointment, and humanity‚Äôs foolish quest to live in places that nature does not want mankind.

articles.title: Flyperbole: Bird Wars

articles.description:
Heather Barry / SB Nation
    

  
More data, hot off the presses!
 It isn‚Äôt an exaggeration to say that Cam York was a real breath of air for the Lehigh Valley Phantoms when he finally made his professional debut back in April. His impacts at 5-on-5 were pretty immediately felt, between playmaking and puck moving, adding an extra bit of dynamic skill to a team already pretty well stocked with it. 
But while those impacts have been well documented and discussed, we (or me, maybe it was just me) couldn‚Äôt shake the feeling that where York gave the team a real boost was on the power play, but we didn‚Äôt really have the same wealth of data as we do at 5-on-5 to confirm or deny that. Well, until now!
We‚Äôre here today, with data in hand, to have a look back at York‚Äôs eight games on the power play‚Ä¶
articles.title: Tracking Cam York‚Äôs impacts on the Phantoms‚Äô power play

articles.description:
OurSports Central
    

  
The son of a former Flyer!
 Continuing on with the theme of players who had to switch leagues due to COVID cancellations, we have Cole Sillinger. Unfortunately, similarly to the OHL, the WHL also had its season suspended, and as a result, Sillinger opted to play in the USHL this season instead of with the Medicine Hat Tigers (amazing team name). 
Sillinger is a very interesting player for a couple of reasons. First, he is the son of former NHLer and first round pick Mike Sillinger, who played primarily with the Red Wings and Islanders, though he did have a stint as a Flyer from 1997 to 1999! Second, and more importantly, he is a consistent scorer from his center position, and can also play on the left wing. He managed 20+ goals in the WHL in 2019-20, as well as i‚Ä¶

A scoring center, you say?
 This season has been, if nothing else, one of adjustments. We‚Äôve seen that really across the board, but we‚Äôve seen it particularly with our next player up on the draft board. 
With the OHL season ultimately being cancelled this year, that left Mason McTavish, who spent last season with the Peterborough Petes, in a bit of a bind. Finding a way to get playing time was going to be a challenge, but it‚Äôs one that perhaps still worked out for him, as he got an early taste of professional hockey this season, as he got in a handful of games with EHC Olten, in Switzerladnd‚Äôs second-tier professional league. It was an abbreviated look, to be sure, but he was able to find a way to be effective in a league full of grown men, and ‚Ä¶

articles.description:
Photo by Len Redkoles/NHLI via Getty Images
    

  
Today‚Äôs open discussion thread, complete with your daily dose of Flyers news and notes‚Ä¶
 It‚Äôs been another ‚Äúfun‚Äù day of the NHL offseason (notice how fun is in quotes there, implying that the Flyers missing the playoffs is not, in fact, fun). Here are some links to pass the time.
Flyers News
*Among the multitude of defenders that have been named as reputed targets for Chuck Fletcher and co. this offseason, Matt Dumba is arguably the most interesting and risky. How exactly does he fit? (BSH)
*With the Flyers increasingly associated with Buffalo star Jack Eichel‚Äôs name in rumors, comments are coming out about the Sabres‚Äô asking price for a trade. Apparently it‚Äôs pretty absurd. (Philly Hockey Now)
*Continuing BSH‚Äôs community draft board, Maddie took a look at arguably the highest upside player in the 2021 Entry Draft. Swedish goalie Jesper Wallstedt is a potential gem and looks like a franchise talent, much like Jaroslav Askarov of the 2020 class. (BSH)
*The Orange & Black owe their fans a lot of things, but they can start by picking a better goal song. ‚ÄúFeel The Shake‚Äù is lame. (BSH)
*Philly legend Reggie Leach went on Sportsnet‚Äôs ‚ÄúLead Off‚Äù radio show to discuss Indigenous People‚Äôs Day and what it means to him. (Sportsnet)
Around The League
*NHL fans have been subjected to some... questionable officiating in this postseason. Absolutely nobody is shocked. (The Hockey News)
*The Islanders have sold out their first batch of season tickets for their new arena in Belmont. That‚Äôs excellent news for the NHL as it transitions to ESPN for a new TV deal, but not so great when considering that the Flyers will have yet another tough road environment in the division. (The Hockey News)
*People decided to say some nasty things on Twitter after Robin Lehner was announced as Vegas‚Äôs starter for Game 4. The veteran netminder kept those comments in the back of his mind and played with a chip on his shoulder en route to a win. (ESPN)
